content: Meeting starts in 5 minutes :slight_smile:

Potential agenda items:

  • Take a moment to celebrate the amount of work done this week :slight_smile:
  • Sync-up of what everyone's working on
  • rustc integration
  • rust-analyzer, in particular ambiguous associated types
beat me to it lol
To add to that:
https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/331
I don't know if we can have a solution for associated types at the moment.
But I guess Niko's recursive solver fits into that
Also, minutes from the last few meetings have been added, and I'll try to keep it up to date
@WG-traits Meeting time
(not a member, but listening in!)
@David Barsky you're always welcome :)
So there were 5 PRs merged into Chalk yesterday
Yeah, lots of improvements around the interner
Shoutout to @Jane Lusby for the Interner work
Also, looks like the book wasn't updated?
@nikomatsakis
Indeed, lots of good stuff going on

Jack Huey said:

Also, looks like the book wasn't updated?

hmm good call
oh yes
http://rust-lang.github.io/chalk/book/engine.html
one other thing worth mentioning
this coming Friday at 10am (Eastern time) is the compiler team design meeting, the topic is the "plan to centralize types"
I'll be around
I shared my write-up in #wg-traits > upcoming design meeting on chalk-ty
still need to look at the write-up though
I was just editing it and planning to share a bit more broadly in #t-compiler

the short version is:

  • describe how chalk-ty is generic and the overall setup
  • discuss how we could refactor rustc to share a library
exciting stuff

but the last point is interesting, as I think there are two general routes -- probably the way that seems most practical to me, at least to start, is to extract the library "in tree" as a kind of rustc-ty crate
then either publish that to crates.io and have chalk use it, for now, or else vice versa? it depends a bit on how we want things setup
that was the part I was just editing
I think working on the rustc integration will really help inform that
I'm not sure if that is worth trying to "decide" at this point or maybe it's worth worrying about when it gets closer
yes, rustc integration is one question -- i.e., I think the end goal is that they share a library, and hence have zero "impedance mismatch"
There are a lot of rust types that just map to chalk TyData::Apply right now
yep
but we could have a time when we are (a) creating rustc-ty and (b) also having chalk-ty that we map to when using -Zchalk, and the two are growing more similar, and that would be ok
Late but I'm here
So, what all would be in rustc-ty?
that would definitely make it easier to make changes from chalk's side
Ty?
TypeFolder?

Jack Huey said:

So, what all would be in rustc-ty?

same as what is in chalk-ir, more or less
at least to start
I feel like actually TypeFolder would actually be a good place to start?
maybe?
Not sure what you mean by that
I guess I'm thinking about how to split out a library that both chalk_ir and rustc-ty can depend on
but I don't know if that's worth it
I mean eventually I think chalk-ir and rustc-ty shiould be the same library, whatever it's called
I just think that it'll be easier to do the refactoring of rustc "in tree"
right
I am also somewhat unclear on how we should setup our brave, new library-ified world
I personally would like to have multiple repos, as I think the dev experience is so much nicer, but it's also kind of a pain
i.e., coordinating rustc changes and having to publish new versions to crates.io and the like
there was some related discussion about that for tooling around rustc
it's kind of a separate topic but it will become something we have to decide
yeah, was going to mention that
#t-compiler > toolstate breakage had some interesting ideas
I don't have strong opinions one way or the other?
but should we circle back to our agenda?
sure
(this feels like something we can dig into async, or on Fri :)
So, sync-up?
I'm still mainly working on the rustc integration
Had some time on the train last week, so I used my offline time to do a couple small things in Chalk
@Jane Lusby's Interner changes work well
It was mentioned that those changes were fairly important for rustc integration, did that unblock further work?
@Jane Lusby are you pursuing the follow-ups there?
@detrumi in progress :)
or rather, planning to, no pressure :)
yea, I hope to get more done on the intern_parameter pr today based on comments yall left this morning
I got around the blocking temporarily by unsafe lifetime transmutes (for testing)
but that's not a real solution
Ps, I've been trying to update the skill tree with some of the latest developments
I updated the wg-traits project a bit

nikomatsakis said:

Ps, I've been trying to update the skill tree with some of the latest developments

ooh fancy
I still feel like we're kind of laying the track as we go a bit more than I would like when it comes to planning but that's ok :)
Does the watch mean "come back to it later"
yeah, blocked
:raising_hand: means "help wanted"
:working_on_it:️ means "assigned"
and there are links to gh issues
planning further ahead is something for next sprint :slight_smile:
You can cross off remove old chalk support
true, that is at least assigned
merged?
did it merge? I am behind on GH notifications again
yeah last night
already reverted/rebased in my PR
(I was thinking btw that updating the skill tree to track what's going on etc might be a nice structure for the meeting)
I've been kind of slow on the debruijn stuff
I think that's actually the next "blocker" for rustc
I feel like I've said that
I'm not entirely sure how to go from Chalk to rustc
like, with a given solution
Oh, and "well known" traits (aka Sized)

Jack Huey said:

I think that's actually the next "blocker" for rustc

agreed
this is why I started on it
I'll try to carve out some coding time, I don't think it'll take me that long (famous last words)
as for well-known traits, those are good items to identify, I am going to add to skill tree now, we can talk over the plan there, did you do any experimenting with T: Sized?
I'm gonna pull that out on you when it takes a long time
I didn't do any experimenting
I'm more or less hijacking the auto trait methods for initial testing
but that's not right
also, @detrumi, I will try to review the impl trait PR, but I guess the question now is to look at "next steps", like how we would itnegrate this into rust-analyzer?
Right, that would be a good way to test it
Type aliases (the third kind of alias next to associated types and impl trait types) is still missing, but I feel like that's both easier and less important
Exciting
I am trying to think
the PR presently assumes that the hidden type is known
Wouldn't that be the most common case?
yeah. I'm just pondering the "full workflow" and how best to think about it
by that I mean
we need to do the inference, that's not necessarily chalk's job, more like type checker

I just thought it might be useful to sketch out how rustc does this and think carefully about "this part is chalk's job" and "this part is the host environment's job", i.e., to show how it's expeted to be used
maybe chat about it with @Florian Diebold
Another question about rustc integration?
How do we/should we handle references?
references?
&T

nikomatsakis said:

I just thought it might be useful to sketch out how rustc does this and think carefully about "this part is chalk's job" and "this part is the host environment's job", i.e., to show how it's expeted to be used

wouldn't it be easier to experiment with this with RA? Or do you think we might put the separation line in the wrong place?
(also, @Jane Lusby, I know I still owe you some stuff on Predicate refactorings etc, I was thinking about that today and about which would be best place to start)
@Jack Huey I think they are just Apply
Its not urgent given you gave me a bunch more to work on for the Interner
i mean, unless you'd rather me focus on the predicate
its up to you, I dont have a good picture on which is more urgent

nikomatsakis said:

Jack Huey I think they are just Apply

Do we have to worry about the lifetime though?
Apply with two arguments
one lifetime, one type
see also this table mapping rustc types to chalk-ir
though not in great detail
Oh I forgot about that

detrumi said:

wouldn't it be easier to experiment with this with RA? Or do you think we might put the separation line in the wrong place?

sorry, yes, I think it's useful to also compare against rustc, but I would expect to be doing the experimentation in rust-analyzer
that said, @Jack Huey, one of the things I am not convinced of yet
when it comes to chalk-ir
is that I think we may wish to expand or modify set of variants
also, I think that we would need to make
well I guess we just need to expand TypeName potentially
to include all those cases
e.g., references etc
at first I was going to say that
TypeName should be part of the Interner trait, so that e.g. rustc can customize it
that might be convenient in the short term but upon further reflection I think it's not what we want long term
So far, I just made a wrapper around DefId
since the goal is for chalk-ir to be "the shared type library" so it should define all the relevant kinds of types
for comparison, here's RA's TypeCtor (which we intern to get a StructId for Chalk)
that's useful
yes
(we don't deal with lifetimes so far though)
@Florian Diebold woudl you be interested in finding a time to chat a bit about how to integrate impl trait with rust-analyzer plus chalk?
(we could even chat a bit now, not sure @Jack Huey where we are on our agenda :)
sure
rustc integration was one of the agenda items
current status of rustc integration in my mind is "jack is trying it out and making updates to chalk that seem useful"
basically
I wouldn't want to kick the 'ambiguous associated types' point off the agenda though ;)
but maybe I should be reviewing your branch to help share what I had in mind? e.g. it sounds like we should discuss the type-mapping and whether to extend TypeName or what
but more like "jack is doing his best to figure things out"
yes please review
I did already plan to review just didn't get to it

Florian Diebold said:

I wouldn't want to kick the 'ambiguous associated types' point off the agenda though ;)

as I type "other than that, @detrumi suggested associated types?"
@nikomatsakis let's plan out a time on Friday to discuss? If you have time
And we can move on for now
~20 minutes left
so, associated types
I don't think we really made any progress here
https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/issues/234
Yeah, I am still interested in trying the recursive solver approach
But I haven't made any progress towards doing that
I had tried to do some work by sort of "tracking" the associated type history (put extremely simply, since I don't quite remember)
There are I guess a few other candidate ideas, e.g. @Jack Huey had the approach where we augment types to track when a result came from normalization
(we had a Hackmd doc somewhere)
I need to dig those back up
the big thing with my branches that I think we decided against was removing Normalize
I'm still nervous about the idea of having types that carry more information than the type itself
e.g., that have the "history" of the associated type they came from
but
hmm so there is this other algorithm
it's called congruence closure
maybe not all that directly relevant but the idea is
suppose you know that X = Y
then you also know that F(X) = F(Y)
(presuming F is some pure function)
hmm
and you also know that F(G(X, Y)) = F(G(Y, X)) and so forth
this is relevant to associated types for sure in that associated types (and any alias) can be seen as a "type function"
so <T as Iterator>::Item is kind of (Iterator::Item)(T)
and you can view normalizing as creating a "congruence edge", i.e., (Iterator::Item)(vec::IntoIter<u32>) = u32
at some point I had an implementation of this algorithm for congruence closure
that would take into account facts like that
and compute the implications
(the code may still be in the ena library)
sounds somewhat interesting
I was intending for it to be used with associated types but I never quite figured out how :)
but in short
I guess the question is when do you deal with congruence edges
while I don't love the idea of tracking in the type that it "came from" a normalization
ah, well, there is another complication
let me finish my thought before I get to it
I was going to say I don't mind the idea of tracking outside the type that we found things to be normalized
i.e., maybe the Forest also tracks "congruence edges"
and then we could use that to normalize or disambiguate somewhere
one complication though is that you also need to take the environment into account
Sounds similar to just how inference variables work?
eh, maybe not
I'm not 100% sure what I'm proposing yet :)
I'm sort of imagining though that
when we solve a Normalize goal, for example
we might "register" that normalization somewhere
yeah, I'm following
it is making the engine (potentially?) more aware of normalization, though not necessarily, it could happen at different levels
I guess then that the "aggregator" would say "ah, we have two distinct types,
but one is a placeholder,
let me check if that placeholder was ever normalized with this type"
(this is roughly what your branch was doing, @Jack Huey?)
(except that the data was sort of stored "in" the type, right?)
uh, I don't remember
trying to think
I think so, yes
I believe so
I didn't quite get there
it would help address the ambiguity but there is another concern that is not addressed by what I wrote above
which is that the SLG solver today winds up doing "extra" work, since it will always get two answers for normalizeable assoc type
and it will process them both
even if they wind up being "equivalent" in the end
that may or may not matter in practice
but it was the kind of thing the recursive solver was trying to address
it might be possible to use the "congruency table" to address also the extra answer problem
but less obvious just where to insert checks
Yeah
I mean, you could imagine that could be checked in pursue_answer
Alright, did not expect the issue to be that complicated :slight_smile:
I think I'll have to think more about this
@detrumi it's quite a complicated issue
Anything else to discuss in the last 3 minutes?
probably not
@nikomatsakis I'll try to think about this, review my branches, and we'll discuss another time
for the last 2 minutes
Yep. I'd like to carve out time to also start on recursive solver. We used to have one and I have a pretty complete sketch in my mind
just a note that we're halfway done with the sprint :)
only halfway? feels like we're nearly done
Sprint ends March 24
3 weeks
(with the amount of work being done, but I guess there's still a lot left)
Things "left" in the sprint
1) impl Trait
2) @David Barsky with tracing
3) Finishing Interner refactor

one thing: I'd like to make "update the skill tree" with progress and new plans be part of this meeting, so if people have suggested for details or how to restructure, I'm all ears (feel free to tell me this thing is not that useful :) but I';m finding it helpful at least as I feel a bit more "on top" of what's going on)
Yeah, I like the skill tree
one other thing worth mentioning: I've been talking some to @eddyb (known zulip hater) about some of the work they've been contemplating on rustc's trait system
and I'd like to try and draw some of that work together here and coordinate
(also it's 5 for anyone who has to leave. Thanks for attending!)
(I think it fits fairly well into this general plan of "move rustc and chalk closer together")
For sure
I actually have a hard stop today, good chat today y'all
(just that rendering is broken when I view it in Firefox)
heh I'd love to spend some time also making it look beautiful
except I know that is an endless yak shave
minutes for this meeting
Thank you @detrumi !

nikomatsakis said:

one other thing worth mentioning: I've been talking some to eddyb (known zulip hater) about some of the work they've been contemplating on rustc's trait system

hey now I only had Zulip hidden because I was drafting some stuff related to the trait system :P
